awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Solid-State Selenium Photo-multiplier with a High-K Dielectric Blocking Layer for High, Noise-free Avalanche Gain
awd_abstract_narration:
Proposal Number: 2048390 (Lead), 2048397 & 2048400
Principal Investigator: Amirhossein Goldan (PI), Ayaskanta Sahu (Co-PI) & Dragica Vasileska (Co-PI)
Title: Collaborative Research: Solid-State Selenium Photo-multiplier with a High-K Dielectric Blocking Layer for High, Noise-free Avalanche Gain
Institution: State University of New York Stony Brook (Lead), New York University & Arizona State University


Nontechnical Abstract
The search for a solid-state photodetector that mimics the behavior of a classical vacuum photomultiplier tube has been a long-standing quest because of the highly stochastic impact ionization process in single-crystalline semiconductors. Amorphous selenium is the only disordered semiconductor that produces avalanche multiplication gain while exhibiting a very low excess noise factor due to non-ballistic and single-carrier impact ionization. The primary objective of this project is to fabricate and characterize high sensitivity solid-state photomultipliers by fully exploiting the deterministic avalanche multiplication properties of amorphous selenium via a solution-processed oxide blocking layer with a high dielectric constant. From the theoretical perspective, the noise-free nature of the hole impact ionization process will be modeled in amorphous selenium to enhance scientific insight into hot carrier transport in disordered structures. The resulting technology can be utilized in a wide range of advanced fields and applications such as medical diagnostic imaging, high energy physics, Cherenkov imaging detectors and trackers, optical communications, and time-domain spectroscopy. The broader impact of this project involves training of students (graduate, undergraduate, and under-represented) in this exciting field of research, and dissemination of tools and materials online.

Technical Abstract
Amorphous selenium is poised to revolutionize solid-state photodetection and imaging through its noise-free single-carrier avalanche multiplication gain. Currently, to achieve high dynamic range and linear mode operation, the detectors used for low-light detection are almost exclusively made of vacuum photomultiplier tubes, where only electrons exist and are multiplied deterministically by the dynodes. However, photomultiplier tubes are bulky, have poor quantum efficiency in the visible spectrum, and cannot be made into an imaging array. Although solid-state crystalline semiconductors are also used as avalanche photodiodes, the amount of enhancement in signal-to-noise ratio is often severely limited by excess noise due to the stochastic nature of the avalanche impact ionization process. Thus, the optimal signal-to-noise ratio typically occurs at very low gains. This work proposes a true solid-state alternative to the vacuum photomultiplier tube using amorphous selenium as the bulk avalanche i-layer, which is a unique disordered photosensing material. In this amorphous selenium layer, hole carrier transport can be shifted entirely from localized to extended states, where holes experience deterministic and non-Markovian impact ionization avalanche. To utilize this material property in devices and imagers, and to achieve reliable and repeatable avalanche gain without irreversible breakdown, a non-insulating n-type hole-blocking/electron-transporting layer is required. This work proposes use of room-temperature, solution-processed quantum-dots, as the high-k dielectric hole-blocking n-layer. Solution synthesis of colloidal quantum dots allows for high-quality stoichiometric and vacancy-free crystals with potential for room-temperature deposition in the desired reverse-biased p-i-n structure, without inducing any crystallization of amorphous selenium, as opposed to other incompatible high-temperature fabrication techniques. This methodology enables, for the first time, reaching an avalanche gain of 10E6 or beyond using a solid-state material. Computational models that explore the physics of the hole blocking layers shall be created to understand and optimize device performance. To this effect, an in-house kinetic Monte Carlo code used to model transport through defects will be developed.  Next, an in-house full-band Monte Carlo simulator, that utilizes the full band structure of selenium, will be established to examine the hole impact ionization process in bulk selenium. As a final step, the kinetic and the full-band Monte Carlo results will be coupled for computer-aided design simulations, to provide design guidelines for the fabrication of more efficient selenium photomultipliers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Project Objectives and Goals

The central goal of the project is to address the limitations of conventional PMTs by exploiting the unique properties of amorphous selenium. a-Se is a disordered photosensitive material that enables carrier transport to shift from localized to extended states, where only holes undergo deterministic and non-Markovian impact ionization avalanche. This feature is crucial for developing a low-noise, solid-state alternative to PMTs, offering robust and compact detectors that operate effectively across the visible electromagnetic spectrum.

Major Accomplishments and Activities

Over the course of three funding cycles, the project has achieved several key milestones, focusing on theoretical modeling, device fabrication, and experimental validation.

Theoretical Modeling and Simulation

A significant portion of the project was dedicated to developing advanced simulation frameworks to predict and understand the behavior of a-Se-based detectors. The research team employed a multi-scale simulation approach, incorporating Technology Computer-Aided Design (TCAD) and Monte Carlo-Boltzmann Transport Equation solvers to model critical aspects such as dark current density, electric field distribution, and impact ionization mechanisms.

  • Modeling Dark Current Density and Electric Field Distribution: The TCAD simulation framework was essential in optimizing the integration of high-k dielectric materials, such as Strontium Titanate (STO), as hole-blocking layers (HBLs) in a-Se detectors. These simulations demonstrated that incorporating STO significantly reduces dark current density and mitigates dielectric breakdown, thereby enhancing the detectors' performance and reliability under high electric fields. The reduction in dark current density is crucial for improving the signal-to-noise ratio (SNR), particularly in low-light detection applications.
  • Investigation of Impact Ionization Mechanisms: The Monte Carlo-Boltzmann Transport Equation solver was utilized to model high-field hole transport in a-Se semiconductors. By introducing history dependence in the carrier branching process and minimizing "dead space/length," the research team successfully reduced the excess noise factor (ENF) to below 2. This reduction is a critical achievement, enabling more efficient avalanche photodiodes (APDs) that can significantly improve SNRs in applications such as medical imaging.
  • Analysis of Non-Markovian Behavior and Noise Reduction: The simulations also focused on the non-Markovian nature of the hot hole branching process in a-Se. As the electric field increases, the tail of the threshold distance distribution decreases, resulting in a more Gaussian distribution and improved non-Markovian behavior. This enhancement contributes to noise reduction and better overall device performance.

Device Fabrication and Experimental Validation

In addition to theoretical modeling, the project has made substantial progress in the fabrication and testing of a-Se-based detectors. The integration of high-k dielectric materials, particularly STO, into the detector design has been a critical development.

  • Integration of High-k Dielectric Materials: The incorporation of STO as a hole-blocking layer has effectively reduced the electric field at the HBL/high-voltage-metal-electrode interface. This reduction minimizes Schottky injection from the high-voltage electrode, preventing Joule heating and the subsequent crystallization of the a-Se layer. As a result, the detectors exhibit performance characteristics like traditional PMTs, with the added benefits of solid-state technology, such as increased robustness and compactness.
  • Experimental Validation and Simulation Correlation: The project emphasized validating simulation results with experimental data. The close alignment between simulated and experimental results has been crucial for refining the models and ensuring their practical applicability. The predictive insights provided by the TCAD simulations have guided experimental fabrication and characterization processes, leading to optimized detector designs.

Educational Impact and Dissemination of Knowledge

The project significantly impacted education and knowledge dissemination by training graduate students in advanced semiconductor simulation techniques, enhancing their technical skills and preparing them as future scientists and engineers. The research findings were widely published in peer-reviewed journals, contributing to the scientific understanding of a-Se-based photodetectors and highlighting key advancements such as the development of non-Markovian hole excess noise models and the integration of high-k dielectric materials in photodetectors.

Key Outcomes and Impacts

The project's outcomes have significant implications for advancing photodetector technology:

  • Advances in Photodetector Technology: The development of low-noise, high-performance a-Se-based detectors marks a substantial advancement in photodetector technology. These detectors offer a promising alternative to traditional PMTs, with potential applications in fields requiring precise light detection, including medical imaging, high-energy physics, and optical communication.
  • Scalability and Commercial Viability: The integration of high-k dielectric materials into the detector design enhances scalability and commercial viability. The predictive modeling provided by TCAD simulations supports the refinement of fabrication processes, paving the way for large-scale production and commercialization.
  • Impact on Medical Imaging: The newly developed a-Se-based avalanche photodetectors hold significant potential for medical imaging applications. Their ability to operate with low noise and high dynamic range makes them well-suited for low-dose X-ray imaging, offering improved spatial resolution and reduced noise-critical factors in medical diagnostics.

In summary, this NSF-funded project has made substantial progress in developing scalable, high-performance a-Se-based detectors. Continued research and optimization are expected to further enhance these detectors' capabilities, facilitating their adoption in various photonic sensor applications.
